awd_titl_txt: LOUIS STOKES B2B ALLIANCE: Metro Denver STEM Alliance - Strengthening URM Student Pathways to College & Careers
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Alliances for Minority Participation (LSAMP) program assists universities and colleges in their efforts to significantly increase the numbers of students matriculating into and successfully completing high quality degree programs in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) disciplines to diversify the STEM workforce.  Particular emphasis is placed on transforming undergraduate STEM education through innovative, evidence-based recruitment and retention strategies, and relevant educational experiences in support of racial and ethnic groups historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines: African Americans, Hispanic Americans, American Indians, Alaska Natives, Native Hawaiians, and Native Pacific Islanders.  These strategies facilitate the production of well-prepared students highly-qualified and motivated to pursue graduate education or careers in STEM.

For the United States (U.S.) to remain globally competitive, it is vital that it taps into the talent of all its citizens and provides exceptional educational preparedness in STEM areas that underpin the knowledge-based economy.  The Metro Denver STEM Alliance (MDSA), a LSAMP Bridge to the Baccalaureate Alliance project led by the Community College of Aurora and in partnership with four community colleges - Arapahoe Community College, Community College of Denver, Front Range Community College, and Red Rocks Community College - was formed in response to the need for a more diverse and skilled technical workforce.  That need still exists and is particularly acute in the State of Colorado.  MDSA will build on research-based models which have proven successful in improving degree completion outcomes for underrepresented minority (URM) STEM students through a focus on engagement, capacity building and continuity.  This focus supports the National Science Foundation's strategic goal to "cultivate a world-class, broadly inclusive science and engineering workforce, and expand the scientific literacy of all citizens."  In support of the focus, the Alliance will engage targeted students in STEM exposure, career and degree planning activities; enhance students' capacity to apply STEM knowledge and skills through project-based learning, hands-on workshops, and undergraduate research experiences; and promote students' continuity through accelerated math remediation, STEM degree progress tracking and coaching, and four-year STEM baccalaureate transfer support.  The Alliance will result in systemic support to URM students from their entrance into community college, throughout their foundational STEM coursework, and to four-year institution transfer, with ultimate engagement in a successful STEM career.  Each strategy adopted by the Alliance is based on best practices for cultivating students' knowledge, skills, and transfer readiness, and informed by an equity approach in which the partner institutions recognize the need to create the conditions in which URM students can succeed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: STATE BOARD FOR COMMUNITY COLLEGES AND OCCUPATIONAL EDUCATION

por.por_cntn:
Community College of Aurora?s NSF LSAMP Project entitled Metro Denver STEM Alliance?Strengthening URM Student Pathways to College & Careers (award No. 1812648 for $1,499,951; award period: 8/1/18-6/30/22; PI: Mordecai Brownlee) connected five Colorado community colleges to constitute the Metro Denver STEM Alliance (Arapahoe Community College (ACC); Community College of Aurora (CCA); Community College of Denver (CCD); Front Range Community College?Westminster (FRCC-W); and Red Rocks Community College (RRCC)) in order to collaborate on increasing the enrollment and transfer rates of underrepresented minoritized (URM) students in science, technology, engineering, and math disciplines (STEM).

Regarding intellectual merit, the Metro Denver STEM Alliance (MDSA) aimed to build upon partnerships, strategies, and processes to increase recruitment, retention, and advancement in URM STEM students? transfer pathways. The LSAMP Program?s advisors (LSAMP Navigators) focused on engagement to recruit new students, offering a variety of events, resources, and opportunities. The MDSA had a website available for students to use to inquire and apply to the LSAMP Program and used flyers and email communications to advertise to STEM students of color. To further engage potential LSAMP students, LSAMP Navigators offered open houses, workshops, classroom visits, and orientation opportunities.

To improve retention and promote transfer success, LSAMP Navigators aimed to build students? capacity and institutional student support infrastructures. The MDSA provided STEM roundtables, mixers, transfer and career fairs, field trips, and workshops in collaboration with numerous organizations and institutions. These activities allowed students to make professional and academic connections while also increasing their interest and awareness of STEM disciplines. According to a survey of LSAMP scholars, 39% of students cited career development as the most beneficial aspect of the LSAMP Program, emphasizing the importance of career-focused workshops and events. LSAMP scholars increased STEM-related skills through opportunities such as the Undergraduate Research Experience (URE) and URE STEM Topic Exploration Program (STEP). Students in these UREs learned about research ethics, methods, and data analysis while emphasizing diversity and inclusion in discussions with industry experts. Students additionally had opportunities to increase their self-efficacy. Nearly all students in the LSAMP Program reported that the LSAMP Program increased self-efficacy for success, with 88% of students reporting that they felt confident that they could be successful in their major and 85% reporting that they felt they could be successful after transfer. Prior to participating in LSAMP, 83% of students reported negative experiences or feelings of isolation related to their identity. By the end of Year 4, 92% of students had seen positive changes in their gendered and racially based experiences as a result of the LSAMP Program. The majority of students felt like members of a community, had access to opportunities, and were more self-assured and empowered because of their participation in LSAMP. The LSAMP Program benefited students by being a STEM-focused community that acknowledged and recognized URM student identities.

To promote advancement, Navigators focused on continuity by streamlining transfer pathways. Numerous visits and meetings with four-year institutions in Colorado helped ensure Navigators were equipped to guide and advise LSAMP scholars in transfer success. Using the ECC Trilogy model, the Navigators at each campus met with students to ensure students felt comfortable with their transfer and career pathways. 27% of students cited advising as the most beneficial aspect of the LSAMP Program, with 85% of students reporting that they experienced support from their LSAMP Navigator. LSAMP Navigator support and advising resulted in 91% of students gaining at least some knowledge about transfer pathways, and 82% gaining at least some knowledge about professional opportunities.

Regarding broader impacts, the Alliance sought to increase the enrollment and transfer rates of URM STEM students. Through collaboration with the CO-WY AMP, the MDSA learned how to better attract, retain, and support URM STEM students. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, each of the MDSA colleges experienced decreases in STEM enrollment and transfer rates. While transfer rates decreased during the height of the pandemic, Year 4 of the grant saw a return to the levels seen in Year 1. In the final year of the grant, the Alliance colleges continued to reflect diversity in STEM enrollments, with minor gains and declines in enrollment percentages filtered by race and ethnicity. From Year 1 to Year 4, overall URM STEM transfer rates increased from 24% to 33%, with transfer equity gaps decreasing from 14% to 10%.

The LSAMP Program proved to be successful in increasing students? skills, self-efficacy, networks, and resources. Students in the LSAMP Program greatly benefited from cross-campus collaboration, individualized advising, internship and career opportunities, and scholarship resources. The LSAMP Program can be used as a model for similar advising and support structures for URM students, both in and out of STEM disciplines. The data, feedback, and structure of the LSAMP Program will greatly benefit further programmatic initiatives for community colleges in the state for years to come.

 


Last Modified: 10/06/2022
Modified by: Mordecai I Brownlee
